page.title: 05History in Hythe.
page.content:
{ Julius Caesar}came to Britain because of the stories of wealth, corn and rich oyster fisheries. Where Hythe now stands there was once an inlet of the sea which flowed where Stade Street and Twiss Road are today and over the present recreation ground, which is still below high water, and it is extended to West Hythe.
The earliest written reference about Hythe is now found in a Saxon grant by{Ethelbert, king of Kent, dated 20th of February 732. Hythe is mentioned in the{Great Domesday {Survey.}At the end of the 18th century,{Napoleon}felt he must crush England, and gathered a vast army at Boulogne.
